description: Installation of water effluent treatment plant, following the removal of a storage container.
subdivision_of_building: New structure within the curtilage of existing factory
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall be begun before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.
REASON
To comply with Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990.

The development hereby permitted shall not be carried out except in complete accordance with the details shown on drawing number 564791-E-00 Rev B and shall thereafter be retained/maintained for as long as the development remains in existence.
REASON
To ensure the development complies with the provisions of The London Plan (2021) and the Hillingdon Local Plan Parts 1 (2012) and 2 (2020).

The development hereby permitted shall not be occupied until the following has been completed in accordance with the specified supporting documents Water Effluent Treatment-Rev-1.0, Report Ref: R100, prepared by Baynham Meikle, dated April 2024 and Planning Statement, prepared by CBRE Ltd, dated May 2024.
Thereafter the development shall be retained/maintained in accordance with these details for as long as the development remains in existence.
REASON
To ensure that the development complies with the objectives of Policies of The London Plan (2021) and the Hillingdon Local Plan Parts 1 (2012) and 2 (2020).

The operation of the development shall not be commenced until an Odour Management Plan has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The Odour Management Plan shall be in full alignment with the Institute of Air Quality Management Odour Guidance (section 7.4) and include, but not be limited to, the following:
(1) Identification of the main sources of fugitive dust and/or odorous emissions;
(2) Potential causes for high emissions resulting from these sources with listing of specific mitigation measures to be deployed as per (3);

(3) Preventative and control measures that will be in place to minimize the likelihood of high emissions from the identified sources, with particular details on management of small waste (small bin) and sludge tank with its associated schedule for emptying and criteria (e.g. emptying only occurring during calm conditions, selected prevailing wind direction, etc);

The storage container located towards the west of the site, detailed in Planning Statement, prepared by CBRE Ltd, dated May 2024, shall be removed from the site prior to the first use of the development hereby approved. Once the storage container is removed from the site, further storage containers shall not be installed on the site without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.
REASON
To ensure the development does not harm the character and appearance of the area and complies with the provisions of The London Plan (2021) and the Hillingdon Local Plan Parts 1 (2012) and 2 (2020).

An Odour Management Plan (OMP) is a live, working document that formalises and describes how odour issues will be managed on-site. It forms part of the operational management system (indeed, it may form part of a site`s wider Environmental Management System or Integrated Management System). An OMP shall show how odours will be managed and controlled to prevent or minimise impact. In addition to covering normal operations, it shall anticipate and plan for abnormal events and foreseeable accidents and incidents.

The site may contain contaminating substances. Our contaminated land record shows it to be on a former contaminated land use identified as Other, Factory (Various), and within 250 metres of a landfill buffer.
We advise persons working on-site to take basic precautions in relation to any contamination they may find.

You are advised this development is on a former contaminated land use identified as Other, Factory (Various), as well as within 250 metres of landfill buffer. Therefore, the above advice is provided on the grounds of Health and Safety of the workers on site and to ensure the appropriate restoration of the site is done should there be any contamination identified during the development where there is a need for groundwork once such works are complete to minimise risk to the occupants of the site.
The Council will recover from the applicant the cost of highway and footway repairs, including damage to grass verges.

Any damage will require to be made good to the satisfaction of the Council and at the applicant's expense.

Nuisance from demolition and construction works is subject to control under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other related legislation. In particular, you should ensure that the following are complied with:-

A. Demolition and construction works which are audible at the site boundary shall only be carried out between the hours of 08.00 and 18.00 hours Monday to Friday and between the hours of 08.00 hours and 13.00 hours on Saturday. No works shall be carried out on Sundays, Bank or Public Holidays.
B. All noise generated during such works shall be controlled in compliance with British Standard Code of Practice BS 5228:2009.
C. Dust emissions shall be controlled in compliance with the Mayor of London's Best Practice Guidance' The Control of dust and emissions from construction and demolition.
D. No bonfires that create dark smoke or nuisance to local residents.
